description.text: Some small lego blocks with extensions to hold the Raspeberry Pi pcb in place

The Pi board is exactly 56mm width (fits exactly within lego dimensions), so the first 2 of the lego blocks are the same, just bare lego blocks with a small extension. For the other side of the pcb, we need some extra adjustments, since it is a little shorter than lego dimensions
1 lego block the extenstion start after an extra 1 mm ridge.
1 lego block the extentions starts after an extra 2 mm ridge.

description.text:
New fan mount for the MP Select Mini main board, I have seen reports where the stepper drivers become overheated cuasing strange print errors.
There are many fan mounts out there but I made this one with fitting ergonomics in mind, connectors can be easily mounted without the cables getting warped under the bracket.

Use a silent 40x10mm fan, solder it to the board at the main power connector, use 12 or 15mm M3 standoffs.

author: hwillumnielsen

print_settings.Notes:: Use 100% infill and 2 perimeters layers for the blades, wing sleeve, wing retaining pins, wing sleeve socket, launch axle and launch handle.  For the launch tube 20%  and 2 perimeter layers is OK.
print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

description.text: The stl file is just a placeholder for now. If you downloaded the other files previously, please do not assemble or fly them. I apologize for the inconvenience.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Low

Infill:

Solid

Notes:

Use 100% infill and 2 perimeters layers for the blades, wing sleeve, wing retaining pins, wing sleeve socket, launch axle and launch handle. For the launch tube 20% and 2 perimeter layers is OK.

Assembly and Flying

Remove the flashing from all parts and give them a moderate sanding. Pay extra attention to the blade roots, the blade slots in the wing sleeve, and the twist socket and where it inserts into the blade sleeve. Sand with medium sandpaper as necessary to get a firm but not too hard fit for the blades and socket. Round the corners of the blade roots a bit so they will fit into the sleeves easier. Use a hobby file to open up the sharp angle where the back of the blades fits into the blade sleeves.

The twist socket fits into the bottom center of the blade sleeve so the thin walled, square looking side projects slightly out of the bottom of the sleeve. The top, twisted looking end of the socket projects from, or is even with, the top of the blade sleeve.

Drill 1/8 inch holes through the blade/sleeve assembly .3 inch back from the blades leading edge and .15 inch in from the outer edge of the wing sleeve. Enlarge the holes enough for the pins to slide all the way through sleeve and blade. This puts the pins through the thickest part of the blades half way between the wing sleeve bottom and its outer edge.

I used Plastruct Bondene solvent cement (found at model train stores and online) wicked into the blade/sleeve, socket/sleeve and wing retaining pins/sleeve/blade joints to reinforce them and allowed the plastic to re-harden over night . Have good ventilation and avoid exposure to the fumes since the solvent contains potentially harmful chemicals

Attach a medium sized rubber band near the top of the launch axle and attach enough chord to the rubber band to allow pulling the chord back to your chin (abouit 40 inches in my case). The rubber band helps avoid damage to the launch axle if you suddenly hit the end of the chord and helps the chord grip the shaft.

Rub wax onto the axle where it contacts the top of the launch tube. Make sure the top edges of the launch tube are smooth. These steps will help prevent plastic erosion where the spinning axle contacts the stationary launch tube.

The chord end is attached to the pull handle by passing the chord through the small hole in the handle. You will probably need to clean the hole with a small drill bit or small round file for the chord to pass through. I used waxed nylon chord to get maximum strength and tied a loop in the chord end after passing the chord through the handle, then put the loop over the shaft. Don't use weaker chords like hemp because they are not strong enough.

Wind the rubber band and chord clockwise (viewed from the top) around the launch axle between where it projects from the launch tube and ends in the twisted plug. The plug at the top of the axle should fit completely into the socket in the blade sleeve and have a bit of friction as it reaches maximum insertion. If the plug does not fit completely into the socket, turn the blade sleeve 90 degrees and try again as sometimes the fit is slightly different. Place marks on the wing and axle plug to more easily find the best alignment.

Give yourself plenty of grassy space to fly in. The prototypes have flown more than the length of a soccer field with a significant wind. If there is wind, pointing slightly into the wind can bring it back closer to you. For safety, keep the Whirligig above your head during the launch just in case a blade comes loose during the launch. Keep all spectators significantly back out of the way for their own safety. Pull slightly down on the string during the launch to keep the launch axle in the launch tube. At the end of the launch pull the rotary wing should naturally slip out of the axle plug and fly away.

If the wing pops off prematurely and does not rise, you may have wound the chord backwards. If it pops off prematurely and rises to a low altitude, insert the blade sleeve socket more fully into the axle plug.

Pulling too weakly on the chord during a launch can allow the wing to prematurely separate from the axle plug. The wing needs to continuously accelerate to the end of the pull for the axle plug to grip the wing effectively through the entire pull.

This is not a children's toy. If used carelessly it could cause injury. Be careful!

Please let me know your experiences with the Whirligig.

Thanks,
MIke.

title: Malyan M200 / MP select mini side cooling 60mm/50mm fan

description.text:
This all started when was doing an 5 hour print for the first time, and I noticed that my LCD was showing pixels with strange colors. So I opened my right side of the printer and felt that the printer board was getting toasty. thats why I desided to design an cooling fan thingie for my Malyan M200.
It uses 1 of the exsisting screwholes for mounting the fan.
It works with any 60mm fan with 50mm hole spacing. I had an 60mm 24v fan laying around, so I used that as my 60mm fan.

I also created one for OneLarge3D's 50mm fan.

I will also include my solidwork files so if you're somewhat familier with solidworks and have the software you could costumize if needed. if thats not the case be free to let me know, and would love to help you!

I would also love, that if you print this model make sure to upload it as an 'I Made One'.

Printer:

Malyan M200

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1-0.2

Infill:

100%

description.text:
Here is a remix version of my quintuple M14 Hex Nuts spinner.

This one is holding 6 standards 608 skateboard ball bearings (Ø22mm), 1 in the middle and 5 on the outside.

Good inertia and around 1min of spinning (depend on your bearing).

This spinner is lighter than my M14 nuts spinner version but the gyroscopic effect is very nice !

Hole diameters is Ø22.1mm for good bearings mounting.

7mm wide for perfect balance after bearing assembly.

I printed it using Blue glow in dark ABS for an amazing show in the dark.

Stop using your pen clicker and start hand spinning !

author: grandcamillou

description.text:
Fully Parametric 3D Printer CoreXY "HyperQbert".

BACKGROUND:

The idea of designing an own printer comes from the Hypercube project by tech2c.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1752766
Many idea's from that printer have been incorporated into this fully parametric design.

OPENSCAD:

The printer has been fully designed in OpenSCAD. This has the great advantage that parts of the objects can be changed and the complete printer can be recalculated to determinate the new dimensions of all the related parts. The OpenSCAD console log summarizes the dimensions of the required extrusions, rods and lead screw.

The printer can also be fully visualized by compiling:

  • drawTotalAssembly()
    or
  • drawTotalAssembly(true)
    to visualize the printer including the enclosure.

MODIFYING THE PRINTER:

The most interesting parameters to change are the following:
1) The buildsize:

  • maxBuildHeight = 300.0; (maximum height of printed object)
  • wHeatedBedX = 213; (width of heated bed)
  • wHeatedBedY = 213; (depth of heated bed)

2) The extrusion profile type:

  • //include "ALU_PROFILE_15x15.inc"
  • //include "ALU_PROFILE_20x20.inc"
  • include "ALU_PROFILE_30x30.inc"
  • //include "ALU_PROFILE_40x40.inc"
    (remove the comment sign of the profile to be used)

3) The bearing sizes per axis (so enforcing the rod diameters)

  • BearingX = LM10UU;
  • BearingY = LM12UU;
  • BearingZ = LM12UU;

4) The motor types

  • motorXY = NEMA17; //NEMA23;
  • motorZ = NEMA17; //NEMA14;

5) The screw size used for connecting the parts:

  • //include "M3.inc"
  • include "M4.inc"
    (remove the comment sign of the screw size to be used)

PRINTED PART LIST:

  • ZCarriage (2x)
  • ZCarriageClamp (4x)
  • ZMotorMount (1x)
  • ZRodMount (4x)
  • LeadScrewNutMount (1x)
  • BedClamp (4x)
  • YCarriage (2x)
  • YCarriageClamp (4x)
  • YRodMount (4x)
  • XYMotorMountLeft (1x)
  • XYMotorMountRight (2x)
  • XYIdler (2x)
  • XCarriage (1x)
  • XCarriageClamp (3x)
  • XCarriageBeltClamp (2x)

OPTIONAL PART LIST:

Optional parts (only needed when second ZMotor is used):

  • LeadScrewNutMount2 (or LeadScrewNutMountBigCoupler2) (1x)
  • ZMotorMount (1x)

Optional Parts (needed only for enclosing the printer):

  • HingeFixed (number dependent on height of printer; dimensions are dependent on thickness of front enclosing panel "tFrontEnclosingPanel", so rerendering required if different front panel thickness is being used!)
  • HingeMoving (same number as HingeFixed )
  • DoorKnop (1x)
  • DoorMagnetClamp (1x)

Optional Parts (needed for microswitch endstops X and Y):

  • XEndstopMount (1x)
  • XCarriageClampWithEndStopMount (1x), replaces one the 3 XCarriageClamps
  • YEndstopMount (1x)

Optional Parts (needed for organizing the electrical wires):

  • "WireHolderClip" (as many as required)
  • "WireHolderClipTieRap" (as many as required)

REMARKS:

  • All parts can be printed without use of support structures.
  • The attached STL's belong to the printer with all dimensions, extrusions, bearings, etc, set to the default values. If you decide to change those defaults, the STL's of course need to be re-rendered using OpenSCAD.
  • I would recommend to choose extrusionLengthBedY longer than the the calculated value. A larger length will give the option to move the heated bed more forward/backward to compensate for alternative extruder dimensions. (40 mm extra should be enough)
  • I recommend to use ABS as material for the printed parts, especially if one plans to build the enclosure around the printer. I printed most of the parts with 95% infill to avoid cracking of the plastic parts when strongly tightening the screws. For the dampening parts I used Ninja flex with 50% infill.

THE PRINTER IN ACTION:

https://youtu.be/3svdtzb3dgA
https://youtu.be/MBuSbpBIuI8

RELEASE NOTES:

Changes 17 December 2016

  • All bearing holders can now self align to ensure smooth traveling along the rods. To disable this feature one can set the variable useBearingSelfAlignment = false;.
  • Y Rod Mounts have now slot holes instead of the original round holes, to allow alignment of the Y-rods.
  • X-Carriage has now an integrated profile to fit the GT2 belt.

Changes 22 December 2016

  • XCarriage and XCarriageBeltClamp now contain an exact imprint of the GT2 belt.

Changes 23 December 2016

  • increased thickness of XCarriageBeltClamp

Changes 26 December 2016

  • alternative Lead Screw Nut Mount called "LeadScrewNutMountBigCoupler" when the very big Z Coupler is to be used (the flexible coupler type with the plastic inserts)
  • mount for X Endstop microswitch : "XCarriageClampWithEndStopMount" + "XEndstopMount"
  • mount for Y Endstop microswitch: "YEndstopMount"
  • fix for XYIdler to avoid collision with the YRodMount in case the Aluminum profile 2020 is used

Changes 28 December 2016

  • support for NEMA14 and NEMA23 motors (not tested)
  • clip for holding electrical wires inside the aluminum profile "WireHolderClip"
  • clip for holding electrical wires with aid of a tie rap: "WireHolderClipTieRap"

Changes 29 December 2016

  • support for aluminum profiles 1515 and 4040 (not tested)

Changes 11 January 2017

  • fixes to ZBearingMount and YEndStopMount
  • added Spoolholder to mount on top of printer (SpoolholderLeft, SpoolholderRight)
  • added ShockAbsorber (printed in Ninja flex) to put underneath the legs of the printer
  • added option to create an extra strong version of the ZCarriage
    samples:
    drawZCarriage(true);
    drawZCarriage(true,45); // will create one arm extra long (can be used if a longer version of the extrusionLengthBedY is used). 45 mm is the extra length of the arm.
  • fixed ZRodMount and ZBearingMount in case aluminum 1515 profiles are used.

Changes 12 January 2017

  • added screw slot holes to ZMotorMount to allow for alignment in y-direction.

Changes 16 January 2017

  • added motor slot hole to ZMotorMount to allow for alignment in y-direction.
  • added camera mount for Logitech C270 webcam (CameraMount).

Changes 3 February 2017

  • added door magnet clamp holder DoorMagnetClamp
  • increased length of spool holder arms
  • closed hammer nut holes for XYMotorMountRight and XYMotorMountLeft
  • added shockabsorbers for XY steppers XYMotorMountShockAbsorber (ninja flex)
  • changed shape of hole in top enclosing panel TopPanel

Changes 17 February 2017

  • support for aluminum profile 2525 (not tested)

Changes 8 April 2017 (added optional X carriage extruder parts)

  • CoolingSystem_Probe_8mm_Offset10.stl
  • Gasket.stl (Ninja Flex)
  • FanDuct2.stl
  • BigGear_Nut.stl
  • SmallGear.stl
  • idler.stl
  • extruder.stl
  • FanSeal.stl (Ninja Flex)

Changes 11 September 2017

  • fixed water-tightness of the XYMotorMounts (both left and right). This issue caused the slicer to create a weaker part then expected.

Changes 24 September 2017

  • made XYMotorMounts (both left and right) much stronger (partially).

Changes 26 September 2017

  • made XYMotorMounts (both left and right) much stronger (the whole part).

Changes 11 November 2017

  • support for second Z-Motor. To enable this feature set variable useSecondZMotor=true. this option has not been tested yet in a real printer. It is on my to-do list to build a printer with a 300x300 build area and use the second Z-Motor for this printer.
  • markings have been put on Carriage clamps (X/Y/Z)
  • the bearing alignment feature can now be enabled/disabled via variable useBearingSelfAlignment

Changes 20 November 2017

  • bugfix undefined variable "correction_BearingRadius"

Changes 26 February 2018

  • added optional holder for LJ12A3-4-Z Proximity sensor (GregMountWithProbe.stl)
  • added support for bearing types: LM8LUU, LM10LUU,LM12LUU
  • removed "useBearingSelfAlignment" variable. This variable has now been defined in the BEARINGS.inc file. For all long bearing types, the self alignment has been disabled.

comments.text:
Even if you don't enclose your printer, at least print your bed mounts in PETG or ABS.
I have an Alucore bed and at 110°C it transfered enough heat into the mounts that it softened and got me into troubles.
Never had an issue with 60°C bed temperature on a fully PLA printed machine however.
My next printer will be printed fully in PETG nevertheless and it will get a second Z motor too.
My first one has a rocking problem with my 326x326mm bed.
Not a huge problem, but I would like to avoid it nonetheless.
comments.author: projunk

comments.text: If your current printer is capable of printing ABS, I would certainly go for that for all parts, to avoid any softening issues.
comments.author: bwct

comments.text:
I don't think my printer is capable of printing ABS.
I almost always print ABS with 60°C and PETG with 70°C bed.
It was an accident and it was capable of heating up to 110°C.

comments.text: Enclosing makes a big difference when printing ABS. I do NOT have a heated chamber, just a full enclosure. I heat up the bed to 100 C and use 3DLAC for better adhesion.

comments.text:
• Set all the parameter the way you want to build your printer (I mean select the aluminum profile type, screw size, nema motor size, etc)
  • Go to the section in the OpenSCad file starting with "// assemblies".
    comment out any line in that section
  • Go to the section in the OpenSCad file starting with "// printed parts" (comment out
    comment out any line in that section, except for the one for which you want to generate the STL.
  • Render the object
  • Export the rendered object as STL

I have started building my Hypercube using your design having modified the Scad to use LM10UU bearings (and 10mm rods), 20mm aluminium extrusion and M3 nuts and bolts.

comments.text: To be honest, automatic alignment of some parts is nice, but not really that important and might just give the opposite effect. If a part is not perfectly according to spec, you might simply not able to achieve the intended alignment. Completely on purpose I defined "clearance" variables (like e.g. clearanceFixedParts) to make sure that also NON perfect parts can be aligned properly.

description.text:
It is designed to fit with 1/4 smooth or threaded rods. But actually I had to enlarge the holes with a drill! The best thing is that you can cut the rod the length you need.

Probably that 6mm rods will fit as well... even better as they are 0,35mm smaller!

It was designed to be fixed with 2 screws, but only one is solid enough for me.

I used #6 5/8 screws witch can be found in any hardware store.

It can fit under a bar, under kitchen cabinets etc.

You have to adjust the width between them using your wine glass. It has to be as tight possible to let de glass foot go between the 2 printed parts.

Hope you'll take some pictures and publish "make"

title: Pen holder for CNC or 3D printer

description.text:
This is a self-sprung pen holder, remixed from here. The point of the remix is to make an OpenSCAD file that lets you increase the width and depth (changing the height will affect springiness) to fit deeper pens, and still keep round (and now adjustable) screw and nut holes.

The default settings are now for a maximum 15mm diameter pen.

This mounts to the cutting/printing head with two screws with centers spaced 20 mm apart. (The spacing doesn't change as you rescale.) You can alternately produce mounting bumps if you are gluing it into a platform that has appropriate holes. (Here's my platform for the Da Vinci 1.0a.)

Printer:

XYZ DaVinci 1.0a with Repetier

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Used a brim to prevent warping.
The 120% size version fits a 15mm fabric marker too snugly (the nut scratches the screw). A touch with a sanding drum might be in order.

I converted the original STL to SCAD using a python script I have here. (You need both stl2scad.py and stl2svg.py for it to work.) I looked where the original holes were with Meshlab, then wrote a bit of SCAD code to fill them in and draw new ones.

author: Audreykit

title: Pool Cleaner Vacuum Hose Connector 1.5" Male Adapter

description.text:
A common pool adapter.  Fits 1.5" hose connections.  Both ends taper from 1.43" to 1.55".
Why buy a new one when yours breaks?  Just print it!

Print it, then if your printer uses ABS, coat it with standard ABS cement to make it smooth, glossy and air-tight. The cement is available at any hardware store in the plumbing department. It is used for gluing ABS drain pipes together. It comes in black and some stores also carry a clear version. It is pretty fast and glues ABS together way better than superglue, everyone who prints in ABS should have a can. The built-in applicator works fine for this project, but you might want to have some cotton swabs around for smaller pieces. Work fast with the cement, smooth it on before it turns gloppy. Don't coat it too thick or it may not fit your hose.

A model from a vintage gas Station, seventess or sixtess

Here is an owl whose head can be rotated to face whatever direction you want. Thanks to @emmett, @BrOncO, and @cushwa for their designs. This is just a little rework of theirs and they deserve the most credit. Here is a little video showing it in "action".

I imported BrOncO's front facing owl into meshmixer and used the plane cut tool in the edit menu to split the head and body into two parts and export them as seperate stl files. I then imported these two stl files into openscad and using the difference module to remove the pinholes from each of the mating surfaces and to generate the pin. I've included a zip file with the source stl files and openscad script for reference.

Cosplay Props with NeoPixels
In this project, you'll learn how to adapt the circuit and code used in this build for your cosplay props. The electronics used in this prop are great for cosplay weapons or really anything that needs to flash when you press a button.

Triggered Lighting Effects
Inside the barrel is a single NeoPixel and mounted behind the trigger is a little push button, so when the trigger is squeezed, it actuates the button and lights up the NeoPixel. The Adafruit Trinket and 500mAh lipo battery are fitted inside the magazine and the entire prop is 3D printed.

Full tutorial: https://learn.adafruit.com/stormflower-gun-blade/overview
YouTube video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P8A5E7oRASM

description.text:
C'est moi Nono le petit robot!

From the famous Ulysse 31 anime TV series.

100% original design to be 100% printable and 3d-print friendly.

As Nono eats nails and bolts, some of them are printables too. Nono can keep it in his belly.

Parts with different colors (eyes, ears, tongue) has specific names.

No needs for glue, all should snap together.

PS: the photo gallery shows a prototype head, with damage marks on it :)

Nono is about 21cm high.

The ear with the hole not centered is the right ear.

Edit : new pump.stl (the first one was an old version)

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Mendel90

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Notes:

Print at 0.2mm with 3 shells (mandatory).

No support needed except for the head; the head should be printed upside down.

The members should fit firmly (if not very firmly) in order to keep Nono stable on his feet.

Torso or head can be printed at normal speed, other parts would prefer (very) slow speed printing.

Print the tongue with a concentric filling pattern to add a subtle realistic touch :)

title: Grimy Grind: Manual Coffee Grinder Bit for Electric Drill/Screwdriver

description.text:
Grimy Grind is a drill bit that connects with a specific manual conical burr coffee grinder to convert it to auto. No need to spend hundreds of bucks on a grinder. This + drill + $20 grinder= good riddance. Booooo expensive grinders.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_n_tG-FGnO4

The specific grinder this bit is for: https://amzn.com/B013R3Q7B2

There are two files. The consumable end should be printed with a high infill percentage(50-60%) and a thick shell. Shell thickness is important because it will keep the actual contact points from stripping. I used 3.2mm and so far so good. The consumable end will eventually strip no matter what, hence consumable and easily replaceable.

The main bit should be printed on its side, otherwise the sheering forces will be moving with the layer's plane which will basically tear the bit in half mid grind.

Uses M3(3mm) hardware. Nuts are M3 .5. Im using 12 mm length because thats what I had lying around.

The nuts are countersunk with a soldering iron. You can check out my process here(very basic): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6nPVWPWAP7g

print_settings.Notes:: The melting point of PLA plastic is 173–178 °C, however I have used temperatures of 80 °C to bend and distort plastic. If you put these into food directly out of an oven they will melt. If the food is not this temperature, please keep in mind the dish itself is most likely well above this temperature. They are 1mm thick, so if your printer cannot handle this thickness I would recommend adjusting them before printing them. I have printed about 20 of these already, so they work for what I need them for on our ROBO3D. As pointed out below, you should print yours with a plastic safe to use with food Happy printing :)

title: Headless Gourd Shaped Pocket Size Ukulele for 200mm Printers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Some has asked me about how to print my gourd shaped ukuleles (e.g. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1868201) on smaller printers as the unibody design requires delta style printers that can print the unit vertically with ~500mm height and 200mm x 100mm on the X-Y plane.

Although the use case of accommodating smaller printers are anticipated in my Gugulele scripts (https://github.com/bguan/gugulele), it may be unclear to casual users how to drive the parameters to make it happen. So I have generated this pocket sized ukulele model (scale length 280mm ~11") to make it possible to print on printers with Print Size ( X Y Z ) of at least 200mm x 200mm x 50mm, and model is to be printed in a horizontal fashion.

The pieces are to be glued together. Through body grooves are there for 2 carbon fiber rectangular rods (e.g. http://www.acpsales.com/.125-x-.325-Rectangular-Rod.html) to counter the strain from string tension. The tuner holes are placed at the tail end, with design that can is compatible with most ukulele and guitar tuners ranging from $5 to $50 units, but some rimming may be necessary.

I haven't printed and made this particular model yet, so please let me know if you've made one and succeeded.

description.text:
Need a little variety on your Christmas tree or are you just tired of your ornaments falling and breaking? Try this present ornament! Durable, fun, and long lasting! You can paint or add glitter to add even more sparkle to your holiday season!

Use Customizer to make it your own! There are options to:
-Change the size and render quality
-generate only the main part of the present
-generate the bow or just separate parts of the bow
So fun even Beyonce loves it!

Instructions

Use customizer to change the size, render quality, and the parts rendered. The hole in the center is used to hang the ornament and is where you should hook the wire or hook to attach to the Christmas tree. You can print the assembled view but there is a possibility of the bow tie drooping. Thus it is recommended that you print the parts of the bow tie separately. After you print the parts of the bow tie which includes hole, loop1, and loop2, glue them on. Additionally you can just print the bow tie without the present.
You can then decorate it however you like! Most Importantly, use it to bring joy and happiness to others during the holiday season.

description.text:
Doctor Strange inspired double finger ring. For creating portals and such.
Initial scaling is off by a factor of 25.4 (mm to in).

Cover photo is a resin print by @particledancer, photo used with permission.

I printed with the rings down and flat front plane with circles parallel to the build plate. The support material was easy to remove from inside the rings, and this preserved the detail on the sides and top of the ring really well.

Status 11/26/16: I'm not continuing to change/add to this design unless there are specific requests, so drop me a message or comment if there's something to look at!

If you want to use this as a jumping off point, the full CAD is public on Onshape. This means you can change all of the parameters, dimensions, lines, thickness, you name it. Linked in the "How I designed this" section.

CAD via Onshape: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/444f3e32c6f5ff43b43bab9d/w/10bba5892553b8c75356bb3e/e/6ba8553da92fb73db7eb55d3
Feel free to branch, edit, etc.

11/14/16 - Added version with D shaped rings and 19.8mm front to back spacing. This is SR-20mm-D.

11/6 - First draft of CAD, going to printer soon and will update for fit and print optimization. No promises it works until then.

11/7 - Printed in woodfill, detail looks great but definitely doesn't fit. Updating for larger size. Will print again tomorrow evening.

11/8 - Printed in glowing PLA. Ring sizing is better, but still uncomfortable. I'm going to adjust the holes to be "D" shaped (thanks for the feedback!) and maybe scale up the rest of the part because I think the larger rings are throwing the proportions off.

comments.text: Ran a print of this today and even the Large won't fit my bit mitts ;)  Makes it to my middle knuckle then no more.  I wish I had the modeling skills to modify it.  Might see if my son can since he's taking Engineering in HS and in his 2nd year of using Inventor.  The vertical gap is ~17.2mm and looks like 19.2mm would be what I would need.  Width is perfect.   Great model BTW! Thx for posting it.

description.text: I have been playing around with the newer releases of skeinforge and thought it would benefit the community to post my cupcake friendly version of skeinforge 49. This requires a stepstruder connected via the ugly cable hack.

This allows skinning, dwindle, and other new features to be used on you old cupcake without any post processing of the gcode. 
If anyone knows how to add a skeinforge version into Replicatorg please let me know.
You need to take a USB component out of an old USB stick. Print all 3 bits and insert the component at the end. Then glue on the top.

description.text:
The basic information is perfectly written down by CherHubert and also in the exploded view document attached.
The reason I redesigned the fan case was because of the thought I needed a better airflow and for sure to get more room for my wiring.
The case now has also 4 blind holes on the Bottom outside in order for me to get the Case bolted down on my machine bed frame. With this option I also could create venting holes in the bottom in order to vent the Arduino 2560.
The latest update from Dec, 2016 has an updated housing and Lid.
The LID now has a better fit to the housing and receives connectors in a better way
Good luck with the make. The Housing is more printing friendly by opening one side of the LCD screen area. This opening is now covered with an added lip on the Lid.
I didn't update the 2D drawings here.
I uploaded a STEP file in order for you guys making your own adaptations/changings
Have fun

description.text:
Micro servo - Size is accurate but if your making sockets don't forget to make it slightly bigger or it won't fit!  
Idea is to use this to mesh in other designs so that you can see if your positioning is correct.  Then you can make a slightly bigger version and use this to make a boolean cut in your model.  
Socket and CAD files also included.  
Updated after using freecad to get rid of non-manifold faces, etc.

Just print it out, or use in cad models to help position your servos.  CAD files (exported from freecad) are also available so you can build your own socket if the supplied ones don't work for your project.  
It's a good idea to just print out the socket before adding to your project so that you can test the exact fit of the servo, cable and horn access, etc.  Make sure you give yourself enough room to snap the servo in once you print your whole model - that's why one of the sides is short in the socket design.

Some has asked me about how to print my gourd shaped ukuleles (e.g. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1868201) on smaller printers as the unibody design requires delta style printers that can print the unit vertically with ~500mm height and 200mm x 100mm on the X-Y plane.

Although the use case of accommodating smaller printers are anticipated in my Gugulele scripts (https://github.com/bguan/gugulele), it may be unclear to casual users how to drive the parameters to make it happen. So I have generated this Tenor sized ukulele model (scale length 430mm ~17") to make it possible to print on printers with Print Size ( X Y Z ) of at least 300mm x 200mm x 60mm, and the model is meant to be printed in a horizontal fashion.

The pieces are to be glued together. The screws are used for decorative and alignment purpose. M1.6x12 for fretboard long holes e.g. http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00XP4OD5Q
and M1.6x4 for body, bridge and fretboard short (mid-line) holes e.g. https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00XP4ZWY2. Through body grooves are there for 2 carbon fiber rectangular rods (e.g. http://www.acpsales.com/.125-x-.325-Rectangular-Rod.html) to counter the strain from string tension. The tuner holes are placed at the tail end, with design that is compatible with most ukulele and guitar tuners ranging from $5 to $50, but some rimming may be necessary.

I haven't printed and made this particular model yet, so please let me know if you've made one and succeeded.

External bluetooth controller for the Synscan hand controller.
Allows remote connection via the handset serial port to read the position of the scope and to slew it to objects in programs like Stellarium.

Only 3 modules inside all available from Gearbest/ebay, no programming (except if you need to reprogram the name and baud rate of the BT module). One spare ST4 cable required as it has the full six wires for powering the modules from the handset and will require one end to be cut off.
Total project cost under 10 UKP which is way cheaper than the commercial versions.

Parts:
ST4 cable
HC-05 Bluetooth module https://www.gearbest.com/other-accessories/pp_227678.html?wid=83
Power convertor module http://www.gearbest.com/development-boards/pp_51010.html?wid=21
RS232 to TTL convertor https://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/2Pcs-Com-Serial-Board-Max232cse-Transfer-Rs232-To-Ttl-Converter-Module-Ic-New-U/132187217126?hash=item1ec6f8dce6:g:GJMAAOSwKOJYIEc4

If the pins on the RS232 module are identified different from the diagram the Tx & Rx pins at TTL levels go to the bluetooth module and the Tx & Rx pins at RS232 levels go to the Synscan.

There are other RS232 convertor module available which are smaller, I only used this as it was the only one I had. I didn't use the RS232 connector on it because the serial cable that comes with the sysncan has no DC power available. Using an ST4 cable means 12V is available for the modules in the bluetooth controller, you will need to cut off one end of the cable and pull back the insulation and connect the following wires as detailed in the included diagram at the pin connections.
PIN 1 - White is +12V
PIN 2 - BLACK is the RS232 Receive line
PIN 3 - RED not used so cut it back
PIN 4 - GREEN is GROUND.
PIN 5 - YELLOW is the RS232 Transmit line
PIN 6 - BLUE is not used so cut it back

WARNING: I accept no liability for any damaged caused by incorrect data, wiring, setup, voltage settings. This project is entirely at your own risk.
DEFINITELY MAKE SURE to set the power convertor to 3.3V output BEFORE connecting to anything else.

Instructions for setting up the name and UART settings for a HC-05 can be found online, UART defaults should be 9600,n,8,1 which will work on the Synscan so this step is only required if the UART settings are not as above or you just want to change the bluetooth device name to something like "Synscan".

Once paired and connected with the host PC Bluetooth the Synscan comms port will be available to set up a new telescope connection in Stellarium. You don't have to go to PC Direct mode on the Synscan for a connection with Stellarium however if you do go into PC direct mode it may also be possible to use ASCOM & EQMod but I never had much success with it (the synscan PC direct interface is not the best and kept dropping the connection).

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8oovtZZ9gMI

This is my first model ever, using Tinkercad. I would love to know what you guys think.

description.text:
When I realized, after some playing, that my tuba mouthpiece was relatively large (larger than an 18 and much larger than a 24AW), I went into designing this one. Made to be printed at 100% infill, this mouthpiece is smaller and easier to control while playing. Its lightweight design helps save plastic, and it is also designed to be injection molded rather easily. It is not an exact representation of a 24AW, but is more friendly to beginning players and advanced players looking for something easy.
Also, it is better for playing higher notes, and gives more control, but less tone canvas to work with.

0.2mm

100%

Notes:

Be sure to orient it in the best orientation. Some parts will droop, this is normal. These parts are made to only droop slightly.
After printing, go over the cup with sandpaper, starting with 100-180 grit and finishing with 400-600 grit.

This is a set of STL files that model up the Folgertech Kossel 2020 which can be set in the Preferences in Simplify 3D so that you can see your printer on the screen. To use the files, put them in a folder and then go into preferences in Simplify 3D and click on the "Machine" tab. Each file is then loaded into the printer models by clicking add. You can load all of them or just some depending on how fast your computer is and how much of the whole printer you want loaded. The X,Y, and Z text components refer to the X,Y, and Z towers and not the X,Y, and Z axis.

Though this was modeled after the Folgertech printer, it will work for any kossel printer that has a 200mm plate. It may also work in other 3D slicing programs that allow your to reference STL files of your printer.

print_settings.Notes:: The lower the resolution, the less chances of your filament catching, but I have also printed at .2 and it is ok for normal filament.

description.text:
If you have a Prusa I4, then you know that it can be a hastle to reach into the extruder to guide the filament from the stepper into the hot end.

I have printed a couple of things from Thingiverse to try to fix the problem, but nothing I have found really fits my model.

So I made something! :D

My initial objective was to make a flexible filament guide, but since I don't have flexible filament yet, then I will just post this as a filament guide.

It is easy to install. Just unscrew the side fan, slide it in and you are ready to go!

It is also an easy way to put the spring under control.

If anyone wants to print and test it then feel free to let me know if it works for flex.

Printer:

Prusa I4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1

Notes:

Print it on its side with the stepper motor groove pointing up. I chamfered the edges on the other side so you shouldn't have to worry about support.

2mm walls don't leave much space for infill.

I have been using PLA which super sticks, so I have not had to worry about rafts or brims.

The lower the resolution, the less chances of your filament catching, but I have also printed at .2 and it is ok for normal filament.
Basically I used Onshape and a caliper.

comments.text: A far easier and better solution is to simply extend the PTFE tube from the hotend and flare it. Same at the top of the extruder, just a piece of PTFE tube. On my Prusa, from the spool to the hot end, the filament rides in PTFE (filament guide, extruder).
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
Thanks for the tip.
I will be sure to try PTFE at the top. (Nice! Works like a charm! I don't even have to aim for the sweet spot.)
Better and easier on the bottom side would depend on a couple of things though. Like whether you have a tube handy (many may not) and if one sets in the hot end side (mine doesn't).
comments.author: MKSA

description.text: This is a common pool hose adapter. It is used to couple a 1.5" hose to the port in a skimmer. You will also need a male-male adapter to connect it to a hose (if you don't already have one). See related thing (male hose adapter): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18740

Print it, then if your printer uses ABS, coat it with standard ABS cement to make it smooth, glossy and air-tight. The cement is available at any hardware store in the plumbing department. It is used for gluing ABS drain pipes together. It comes in black and some stores also carry a clear version. It is pretty fast and glues ABS together way better than superglue, everyone who prints in ABS should have a can. The built-in applicator works fine for this project, but you might want to have some cotton swabs around for smaller pieces. Work fast with the cement, smooth it on before it turns gloppy. Don't coat it too thick or it may not fit.

title: GoPro hero 2 brushless gimbal made for intensewalkera H-copter

description.text:
I remixed Nathan's brushless gimbal for hero 3 to fit my needs. Because I have a Hero 2 and different motors(rctimer 2212-70T) it had to be redesigned. If you want to use it on a TBS discovery you can use a different frame mount.  
It is perfectly balanced for a hero 2.  
UPDATE!: Updated the 90 degree arm. Now it is 8mm thick instead of 7mm. This should remove the 'wiggle' which causes jello when printed in ABS because the old 7mm version lacked stiffness. Maybe if you print it in PLA you don't have that problem, havent tried that yet.  
Also added a mount for the CCD cam, martinez control board and video transmitter.  
I am still waiting on 1 motor before I can do some testing!

comments.text: Yeah maybe, but i like the idea that it is easily replaceable. I flew only once, but I currently have motor problems. So i am still waiting for a new one from rctimer. I did noticed that the camera was a bit shaky. probably because I used not enough infill(30%) for the 90 degree arm. going to try it with 80% infill later to make it more stiff. But first i have to finish my new 3d printer!(kossel)  I will update when i've done some serious test flying!

description.text:
hey folks,

so the fan duct is ready, it fits on an 50mm radial fan

i added a mount for an XT60 plug, solder it to your heater push it tru and turn it, ready ;)
https://hobbyking.com/en_us/male-xt60-connectors-5pcs-bag-genuine.html
https://hobbyking.com/en_us/female-xt60-connectors-5pcs-bag-genuine.html

other things like probe mount follow

the hotend mount screws are M4 (ISO 4762)

the multiplexer screws are M3 (also ISO 4762)

the Pushfits i used for the multiplexer are the original E3D
http://e3d-online.com/Threaded-Bowden-Coupling-1.75mm-Filament?search=bowden

or even this ;)
https://reprapworld.com/products/e3d/spares_and_extras/1_75mm/e3d_v6_threaded_bowden_coupling_1_75mm/

T[old_tool] ; active Tool selected

G1 X0 Y215 F3000 ; Move nozzle behind the Bed

G1 E-0.1 ; Retract .1mm
G92 E0 ; Zero active Tool

title: Print cooling shroud for Anycubic Kossel Mini

description.text:
This is designed for Anycubic Kossel Mini that already has 30mm cooling fan attached to effector in ~20 degree angle. When nozzle touches printbed, clearance to bottom of the fan is only ~3mm.

The fan is attached with 2 upper screws and this goes to 2 bottom screw holes. Originally the fan blows from 3cm distance with no guidance, but this directs the airflow much closer the nozzle.

Print in PLA for accuracy and use raft. Attach with two 14-16mm M3 screws.

Here a fan duct for the hotend on anycubic kossel effector, to avoid cooling the aluminum heater block.
Print right with 0.40 nozzle, thickness 1.6 mm.

print_settings.Notes:: No supports / rafts are required. I've been printing them in batches of 6-10.

description.text:
Needed a simple, light, one-sided roller chain for a project that was easy to print on a basic extruder printer. This is what I came up with. So far it's been printing well in PLA and requires minimal cleanup, if any. It is NOT made to any chain size standards. One part per link and they just snap together. Each link adds 12.5 mm to the chain length (total link length is 18 mm).

Included the original Sketchup file as well. I initially designed it at about 1/2 size - it actually worked as a linkage (so maybe a bracelet?) but looked a bit iffy on working with a sprocket.

There's a demo/test project for it now that uses the chain to spin a sprocket (with a short video).
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1875428

Printer:

da Vinci Mini w

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Printing it with the "Good" defaults, standard speed. Layer height is 0.3mm, some docs seem to indicate x/y would be at 0.2mm res at that speed?

No supports / rafts are required. I've been printing them in batches of 6-10.
Sculpt inspired by Lego Rancor beast (as seen in 75005). It's a work-in-progress so no articulation and the tail seems to be missing. Print with supports everywhere! Good luck.

author: luke2

description.text:
The Ramps Bridge Breakout Board was designed to accommodate all the cables associated with the printer and use a common harness which routes it to the controller which can be housed in an ice box.

Available as KIT, Bare pcb or assembled.

The goal of this chain mail design was to simplify each loop as much as possible so the pattern can be shrunk to a minimum printable size while still maintaining good strength and flexibility. Each loop links 3 of other loops which I think is more flexible (most designs found on Thingiverse link 4). The natural shape for a 3-link loop is a hexagon but I distorted it to a more triangular shape so each link crosses at 90 degrees. This allows the printed gap between loops to be more controllable (so they don't get printed together) and it helps to keep the links from getting tangled.

The finished pattern has good drape and does not tend to get tangled up. You can pretty much roll it into a ball and then throw it on a table and it will lay flat again after a few flicks. My intent was to make a useful fabric but, for now, it is finding much more use as a toy to play around with.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Reprapguru

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

see notes

Notes:

This design is not the easiest thing to print since the goal was to optimize everything else. Do not try to use rafts or brims or you will have to trim the 540 pads one by one. Your printer must be well calibrated and the bed must be flat over the entire area. I had to buy a new Pyrex plate because the original one was warped 0.2mm. Here is the recipe that worked repeatedly for me:
Material: PLA, Bed temperature: 55C. Extruder temperature 210C
Bed coating: blue tape
Infill: none, but make shell thickness 2mm (or 3 lines) so you get 100% fill.
First layer speed: 15 mm/s. This gives the PLA a chance to stick.

You may need to add a z-hop of 0.2mm for long travels in case the extruder is wacking into surfaces it has already printed. This slows things down though and wears on the z axis bearings.
Do a test run with the included test stl file which has only 8 loops.
Keep an eye on the printer during the first layer since this is where most of the problems occur. If one pad comes loose it will make a mess of the rest of the print.

comments.text: I have been experimenting with that and I found a way that works.  You snip a link with a good pair of electrical snips at a non-obvious point (not at the surface).  You can then flexibly pry that link apart and snap it onto the next link.  I made a wrist band out of two separate sheets this way.  I was planning to re-join the broken links with a soldering iron or a hand-held 3D print pen but it turned out not to be necessary.  The broken links were still quite strong and were very difficult to even find.  I will update with some pictures in the near future.

title: Flex Pipe Nozzle Cooler (Radial Fan Attachment)

description.text:
This thing is a remix of the Flex Pipe Nozzle Cooler that had been modified to work with a radial fan. This is a low tech attachment and is design to simply fit around the mouth of the fan where you may then either glue it in place or use tape to form a tight seal. I recommend contact cement for glue as it comes off easily if you would like to modify the fan later. This part is just the fan attachment and you will need the following parts to build the whole thing:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:43272
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:63366

Kudos to mx5 for designing the original thing including the two things linked above.

title: Extruder Cooling Duct for the Anet A8 Printer

description.text:
05.02.2017 - ATTENTION: I no longer recommend this cooler!

Use this version instead: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2086191

I've been printing all kinds of coolers for my Anet A8 printer. Either some are too clunky, too heavy or some don't fit because they are too low or too high. With others the air for cooling is not being drawn to the ideal area on the object. Most of the ones I've tested are designs I made myself.
At the end of the day I have found that the cooler I designed for download here suits my needs the best. It has some similarities with this design which rightly so is the most downloaded version as I post this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1620630
However it didn't satisfy all my needs. The most important reason to design my own was that I have a different filament extruder height. Because of this I decided to design 6 coolers for different heights. They are 25.5mm, 24.5mm, 23.5mm, 22.5mm, 21.5mm and 20.5mm. You will need to measure the height from the bottom of the fan to the bottom of the extruder nozzle. See picture marked with "X". Then subtract at least 1mm to chose which cooler you want to print accordingly.
This cooler also has an opening for clearance of the heater cables.

Attention:

  • The heater block is not centered on the ring. That is intentional! However it is important that the nozzle be in the center of the ring for even distribution of the air.
  • It is recommended that the cooler be printed in ABS or PETG as these filaments are more heat resistant. However I have mine printed in PLA without any issues. When printing ABS or high temp filaments I just remove the cooler. You normally don't print with the fan on for high temp filaments.

Please let me know if you have a problem with the design so I can improve it if necessary.

Also please post a picture with comments if you have made one.

Thanks.

Leo

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The 3D print was made with PLA at 35mm/s with a 0.8mm shell thickness and 0.8mm top / bottom thick closures.

comments.author: Leo_N

comments.text:
Hi, a technical question about the air flow. I have tested other similar designs, and I have created a method of testing the air flow comeing out. Almost all of the designs I haved tested failed in creating a real circular air flow. I have not tested yours yet, but so far looks promissing about this. I would like to know if you have tested the air flow direction, if you can confirm that the air comes out evenly from all holes. Also and most important, since you are the designer: In your picture you show than the cooling fuct should be mounted in a way that there is 1 mm of difference between the noozle tip and the base of the duct, this is the way you have tested that the air flow is directed to the noozle tip and surrounding areas?
Just as an example, the link provided to the other circular disign fails about this . It directs air directly to the noozle but in a very un even way and DIRECTLY to the noozle. It makes the tip of the noozle to cool down A LOT, and I was able to create a clog printing PET because with the fan turned at 100%, the tip of noozle was cooled down to below 220 degreed, and that made pet flow to be so hard that back presure was created.

Because the heater cables have to pass through the ring.
Also the ring will deform in the area where it would touch the heater cables. That happened to me and that is why I made a cooler with an opening.
The opening does not negatively effect the cooling.

author: scurot

description.text: If you like my work I hope you'll consider supporting me on Pateron: https://www.patreon.com/3DPrintingProfessor Subscribe to me on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/mrjoesays In my opinion, MrJaws (and MrAllagator) represent the best thing about having makerbots in the world: That you can mave something functional with an artistic side. That blend of engineer and designer. However, MrJaws was, to me, a little TOO much artistry, speaking in terms of volume. So I decided to make a version that was just as much shark, but heavier on the jaw. Leave me a comment if you would like me to do the same with the alligator.

The STL here is 2x bigger than it needs to be, which is okay for chips but not as good for smaller things. Scale it down for the job you're doing. Print and clip.
Then leave a picture and a comment and check out my other designs. WIP until someone with a printer tells me this'll work (tho I can't for the life of me imagine why not).

comments.text:
The mold can be easily done in Solidworks,
Just design a cube that will be the base of the mold, then insert your part and subtract the part material from the under body, do the same for the upper part, you will have 2 semi parts, (upper positive and lower negative , the gap is your molded part and can be filled with
liquid Silicon.
Remember that the lower part has to be the entire negative, the positive(upper part) is the inside of the mold
If you have critical (draft) angles in the lower part then just split the part in 2 semiparts and keep them together while you are injecting silicon, you can separate them after the silicon is polymerized. (sorry for my bad english)
Of course you have to add the holes for the injection and air exaust on the upper part and the reference pin for coupling.
REMEMBER, IS A PROPER MOLD
It's easy to do, plenty of tutorial on youtube if you are not confident.

title: MP Select Mini Filament Spool Holder for Full Sized Rolls (Malyan M200)

description.text:
I decided to remix the Spool Holder from cantizzy to get proper alignment with the filament intake of the MP Select Mini (Malyan M200). That way the filament can unroll even easier.

I included the 123dx files from Autodesk 123D Design and also .gcode files with settings that worked perfect for me on my MP.

Thanks to cantizzy for the great idea! Also thanks to aubenc for the knob. It looks nice! :)

MP Select Mini (Malyan M200)

Doesn't Matter

No

0.3

15%

Notes:

No supports needed except for the "base_stab". The square hole on the "base" printed perfectly for me without supports. Should also work for you if you use my .gcode files on your MP/M200. :)
Feel free to drill a hole into your original spool holder and screw the new one in place. It's not needed but definitely improves stability.
Modified the spool.stl from cantizzy, remade the base & base_stab completely in Autodesk 123D Design.

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/SJUijbcq86c" ></iframe>
Printing of base.stl. Bridging worked perfectly for me without supports for the hole.

author: Garla86

description.text:
UPDATE: To solve most problems with the y axis see
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1999279

=> See also my other Prusa i3 reworks in my Collection

Brackets for supporting the arms of the y-carriage of an Prusa i3 printer. This will help to reduce wiggling of the y-carriage, with improves printing quality and eases print bed leveling.

Installation might be a bit fiddly, but you don't need to disassemble anything.

Print two copies, one mirrored.

Insert a cable tie from the top half way through the hole. Insert the bracket with the cable tie from the side between the rod and the y-frame. Use a needle-nose plie for tightening the cable tie and a utility knife for cutting.

See pictures for more details.

The brackets will fit at the side with the single linear bearing. On the side with two bearings is no additional support needed.

Print both in on turn. This will give each one the time to cool down between the layers.

image = Chihuahua (Dog)

The Vector 3 3D Printer has the facility to add an SD Card but the socket for it is internal and therefore impractical. By adding an extension cable it is possible to take the SD card outside the case. This could be done by cutting the case but a simpler solution is to route the extension through the existing slot that carries the wiring to the Y-axis. Using this clip it is then possible to secure the extension to keep everything tidy.

Parts (available on ebay/Amazon)
1 x 48CM TF to Micro SD TF Flex Zip Extension Cable Memory Card Extender Cord Linker by LANMU
2 x M2.6 x 7mm self-tapping screws

Instructions

  1. Raise the print bed to give clearance and remove the 'Front Top Cover'.
  2. Insert the plug end of the extension into the edge connector on the main circuit board.
  3. Thread the extension up inside the 'Main Frame Rear Cover' (isssue 44, page 19) and out the slot.
  4. Attach the Clip to the 'Main Frame Rear Cover' using 2 x M2.6 x 7mm self-tapping screws. You will probably find insertion of the screws easier if you drill a small pilot hole for each one. Ensure you do not damage any wiring inside the cover.
  5. Carefully slot the extension socket and ribbon cable into the Clip ensuring you have it the correct way up - both the Clip and the Socket are marked to show the correct orientation of the SD Card.
  6. Ensure that the ribbon cable is tucked out of the way inside the 'Main Frame Rear Cover'.
  7. Replace the 'Front Top Cover'.

Acknowledgement
The idea for this project came from Paul http://v3uc.com/forums/topic/adding-a-microsd-card-slot-to-the-vector-3/

title: Cantilever Brake Set
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
WORK IN PROGRESS. PRINT AT .1 MM RESOLUTION. 100% INFILL. I AM TESTING WITH CARBON PLA. FIRST PROTOTYPE WORKED BUT I DID NOT TEST FOR STRENGTH AS I IDENTIFIED WEAK AREAS. THIS FILE HAS ADDRESSED THOSE ISSUES BUT HAS NOT BEEN TESTED AS OF YET. NOT RECOMMENDED FOR USE WITHOUT FURTHER TESTING. FAILURE IS POSSIBLE. USE AT OWN RISK.

UPDATE: COMPLETED SOME LIGHT TESTING WITH GOOD RESULTS. SOME SANDING IS REQUIRED FOR NOW. I WILL BE MAKING EDITS TO THE FILE TO ELIMINATE SANDING AT SOME POINT. HEAVIER TESTING TO FOLLOW.

UPDATE 04/03/17: I HAVE USED THE BRAKES FOR SEVERAL MONTH MODERATELY WITH NO TROUBLE EVEN THROUGH A VERY MOIST WINTER IN CALIFORNIA. I HAVE NOT USED THE BRAKES ON ANY LONG DESCENTS AND WOULD NOT RECOMMEND UNTIL FURTHER TESTING IS COMPLETED.

UPDATE: CANTILEVER BRAKES HAVE PERFORMED WELL UNDER NORMAL RIDING CONDITIONS WITH A FEW HARD STOPS. HAVE PERFORMED AS WELL AS MY TRP BRAKES. NO SIGNS OF WEAR YET. NO SIGNS OF STRESS FRACTURES OR CRACKS FOUND.

UPDATE:9/20/2017 I HAVE BEEN USING THE BRAKES ON THE FRONT WHEEL FOR ALMOST 9 MONTHS WITH NO ISSUES. I HAVE BEEN ON LONG RIDES WITH 1 MILE DOWN HILL DESCENTS. NO ISSUES. I REMOVED THE BRAKES TO INSPECT CLOSELY WITH NO SIGNS OF WEAR. I AM AN OVER 200LB RIDER AND HAVE BEEN PLEASANTLY SURPRISED WITH THESE BRAKES AND THE CARBON PLA.I STILL ADVISE CAUTION WITH USING THESE.

description.text:
Wanted a cargo net in my car trunk, but the net didn't come with hooks to mount. So I designed and made my own. I have a cargo net in my Jeep, so I patterned it similar to one from the hooks in the Jeep.

This can be scaled to whatever configuration needed. In the bottom is a pilot hole so you can drill to whatever depth is needed and thread in a screw or whatever. The side panels in my trunk are rigid, so I used a panhead phillips sheet metal screw with a fender washer from behind the panel and screwed the hook on.

author: Diyi

print_settings.Notes:: I tried to minimize supports as much as possible, but there are some pieces that require it.  If you print the 3 base pieces oriented the way I uploaded them (vertical) they will only need support in the bearing recesses.   Santa may need support in the hollows where the waving arm will go, and the sleigh will need support where Santa and the bag of toys go.  The crossbars can likely be printed with or without support.  The slots are at 45 degrees, so it kind of depends on your printer.  Everything else should print without supports.

description.text:
Edit 11/11/2016: Made slight change to sleigh that strengthens the peg on the runner. Thanks ctgreybeard for finding this error.

Ho! Ho! Ho! Merry Christmas!

You will need to print:

4 ea Whirligig blades
3 ea Eccentric cams
2 ea Crossbars
2 Reindeer
2 ea Base Couplers
1 ea all other parts

There is a cutaway view in the thing files called cutaway view.pdf showing how the model goes together.

I printed the base sections vertically to minimize support and print time. The tallest one is 148mm. This is the maximum height I can print with my FlashForge Creator Pro with glass bed.

There are 3 cams that have to be placed on the quarter inch rod drive shaft such that they rest directly under the push rods from the reindeer and sleigh. Each cam needs to have a nut on either side to hold it in place and keep it locked to the drive shaft. When assembling, I recommend putting a drop of super glue on the nuts that hold the cams in place once they are positioned. Also, it is probably a nicer effect if the cams are offset from each other so the deer and sleigh are bobbing up and down slightly out of sych with each other.

Because Santa and the bag of toys have details in relief to make painting easier, I have made them with mirror images that will need to be glued together. This way they can lay flat on the print bed. Just glue them together after printing and painting.

I didn't glue the three base sections together because I wanted to be able to disassemble the base if I needed to fix any of the internal parts. The threaded rod and nuts hold it together fine. For the same reason, I made the vane base a tight fit and didn't glue it to the base. The vane should be glued to the vane base, and the whirligig blades should be glued to the crossbars.

I used 6-32 X 1.5" round head screws and nylock nuts for the pivot hinges of the sleigh and reindeer.

For Santa's waving arm, I used an m3 X 10mm screw with internal hex key drive (allen screw) that I had in my printer spare parts box. I don't have a nylock nut for it, but recommend one if possible. I put a drop of super glue on the nut to keep it from unscrewing. I think maybe a 4-40 screw and nylock nut would work for this, but I used what I had on hand. Whatever you use, it needs to have a small diameter head and nut in order to fit into the space available for it. Feel free to substitute whatever you can find that will work for any of the hardware listed.

To make the arm wave, connect a short length of wire (about 20 gauge) from the hole in Santa's elbow, through the holes in the sleigh and base, and then back out of the base through the second hole. Adjust it for tension and to keep it from rubbing on anything.

Here is a video of Santa in action: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_GBQXN-hKXQ

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I tried to minimize supports as much as possible, but there are some pieces that require it. If you print the 3 base pieces oriented the way I uploaded them (vertical) they will only need support in the bearing recesses. Santa may need support in the hollows where the waving arm will go, and the sleigh will need support where Santa and the bag of toys go. The crossbars can likely be printed with or without support. The slots are at 45 degrees, so it kind of depends on your printer. Everything else should print without supports.

Materials Needed

7 ea 1/4 - 20 nuts

3 ea 1/4 - 20 nylock nuts

3 ea 6-32 X 1.5" round head screws

3 ea 6-32 nylock nuts

2 ea R4-ZZ skateboard bearings

2 ea 608ZZ skateboard bearings

2 ea 5/16 nylock nuts

1 ea 1/4 - 20 threaded rod about 20" long

1 ea 5/16 threaded rod to mount whirligig on (size to preference)

1 ea m3 X 10mm screw

1 ea m3 nut or nylock nut

1 ea short length (about 5") of wire about 20 gauge (.8mm dia) or so

1 tube of super glue

comments.text: I just noticed as I was watching the sleigh print that the peg that rides on the cam is printing as a separate piece. It is right next to the runners but definitely a separate part. I think it would be stronger of you could join them together so they print as one part. You can see what I mean here: https://flic.kr/p/EFLboZ
comments.author: ctgreybeard

comments.text: Just uploaded a fixed version.  I don't know how I missed that.  It wasn't even aligned properly with the runner !  The old design works, as evidenced by my prototype, but the new one should be much stronger.  Thanks for finding this.
comments.author: ctgreybeard

comments.text: The new sleigh looks much better. I had already started printing it (along with Santa, his arms, and the toys) at 0.2mm so I will use the older design. It does seem like it will work fine though.
comments.author: Sparky6548

comments.text: I'm also slicing with S3D and am reprinting Santa, the sleigh and the toys at 0.2mm. I just wasn't thinking when I carried the 0.3mm setting over to the smaller parts. Slicing at 0.3mm did make a difference for the tall parts!
comments.author: ctgreybeard

comments.text: I'm not done building yet but I have all the parts printed. Because of my slicing I ended up with Santa and his arms too thick and the slot for Santa in the sleigh too narrow. I reduced the Z height of Santa and his arms to 85%. The arms could have gone to 75% and I may do them a third time, but it looks like they will fit now. I think the problem is that I am printing them at 0.3mm, maybe they should be done at a finer resolution. At least they are small, the base pieces needed 0.3mm just to make the time manageable.
comments.author: ctgreybeard

comments.text: Sorry to hear that you are having difficulty.  I sliced with Simplify3D and printed everything at .2mm.  All the pieces fit together fine for me.  There is some relief detail in Santa and his bag of toys that you will probably lose printing at .3mm, but maybe you are better at painting than I am.  I needed the relief in order to know where each color went.  Kind of like paint-by-numbers.
comments.author: ctgreybeard

comments.text: Under "You will need to print" you should list Reindeer as 2 each.
comments.author: ctgreybeard

comments.text: Oops!  Good point.  Fixed it, thanks.
comments.author: ctgreybeard

title: Two-Part Knife Block cnc/laser

description.text:
When storing knifes in a household with kids it's not the best idea to use a classic knife block. I designed this two-part construction to be stored horizontally in a drawer – and therefore out of reach of the children. It shares the design-principle with Stabilo Stand, but uses M5 threaded bars instead of normal screws.

The build was done on a desktop cnc-machine from Stepcraft from 6.5 mm birch plywood using a spiral-toothed 1.2 mm flute. I finished the knife block with hardwax oil to intensify the wood structure and to make it water-resistant.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs.

Keep in mind , that the stl-file is for viewing only!

author: Serial

description.text:
Cookie Cutter for a Gingerbread-house that sits on a teacup.

Recipe for the gingerbread recipe is down in the "Custom Section"

DO NOT USE ANY TOXIC GLUE IF YOU WANT TO EAT THEM!

Maybe I'll design some sort of holder for easier "gluing" in the future

Gingerbread Recipe

Ingredients:
100g Butter
100g Honey
300g Flour
1 teaspoon baking-soda
100g powdered sugar
1 Egg
1 pinch pepper
½ teaspoon Nutmeg
½ teaspoon Cinnamon
(2 teaspoons Cocoa)

Melt butter and honey together in a pot.
Mix together Flour and baking soda.
The butter-honey mass, the flour-baking soda, powdered sugar, egg and the spices are mixed together to get a nice even dough.
If you want you can dye the dough using cocoa.
Let the dough cool in the fridge for 15 minutes.
Roll it out to 3-4mm thickness.

Cut out the pieces (you’ll need two of each for the house).
Bake them at around 160°C circulating air for about 7 Minutes.
Bigger pieces may need 1 to 2 minutes longer.

"Cookie-Glue"

For the „glue“:

  • beat the egg white from two eggs until it’s stiff.
  • slowly add 400g sieved powdered sugar while beating until it’s a tough snow-white mass.
    If you want it colourful just add some fruit or vegetable juice and some food colour.
    Put the mass into a decorating bag
Steps
  1. Bake the gingerbread dough after cutting enough parts as described in the
    recipe.
  2. Let the parts fully cool down.
  3. "Glue" one piece at a time starting with the base and let the pieces rest for at least 1 minute until "gluing" the next piece. The roof will be the last two pieces.
  4. You can decorate the houses as you wish.

DO NOT USE ANY TOXIC GLUE IF YOU WANT TO EAT THEM!

description.text:
I designed this part to keep my heating element from backing out of head during long prints. As the head moved back and forth, the element would come out the back of the head even though the set screw was tight. My guess is that during the long prints the head is expanding and causing the slipping of the set screw. I use a simple zip-tie to test if that solved the problem and it did.
With that test showing promise, I made this mount to attach to the carriage using the existing screws for the bearing mount. Works like a charm!

I have included all the files, including the gcode file for quick printing.

Printer:

Anet A8 Omini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

1.75

Infill:

.1

Notes:

Brim of 10mm

This design was generated using an algorithm created by one of my research students, Zachary Ash. He has developed a method to map an digital image onto a surface (a manifold), such as the curved part of a cylinder. (The inspiration is George Hart's 3D printed cookie rollers: http://www.georgehart.com/rollers/)

Note that the design is upside down, which yields a better product because then the bottom is completely flat while the top is dimpled.

I've been loving the joy of a wireless digital weather station that measures wind speed, direction, air pressure, humidity and all that good stuff. Thing was mounted to the shed in the garden.
Due to an unfortunate flying tent incident last year, the station got ripped off the mounting brackets, so I figured I'd have a bash at designing a new one and printing it with the UP! PP3D that's turning up tomorrow. Designed for a 21mm tube support and there's some ribs in there that should hold it in tight. 
Let's see how it goes.

Things to note: Built for a 21mm support tube as supplied with most weather stations
Designed to take an M5 machine screw, bolt or whatever. Should be good for most fasteners though.
Bottom of the bracket (both sides) is closed off to help with vertical support and to stop the tube slipping under pressure. Possibly and most probably massively over engineered - but this is the first part I'm building on a 3d printer at home, so wanted to make something that might last a while without having to replace it. That said, the rear support is shelled with ribs, so should save a bit of material. External ribs on the front are help with shear forces. And they kind of match the styling of the weather station itself. Update: Made a few changes to the accompanying PDF with all the key dimensions in place - kind of fascinated with how accurate this UP machine is. Built a half scale copy of one part and it seems about bang on. So now on with the full height, full scale print of both parts. 14 hours. Tick tock tick tock. Final update: Done. Built lovely, installed and clamps up rather nicely with some longish Kreg screws I had lying about. Note, if you're mounting it to wood, then don't use a countersunk fastener, otherwise you'll split it.

description.text:
This is my version of a DIY electric long board, I am still perfecting it and tweaking things currently. I printed the ESC enclosure, battery enclosure and engine shield using wood/PLA filament. I designed the prints to be able to print on a small print bed and so that they wouldn't break when the board flexes. The battery enclosure is three pieces. The motor mount when printed in pla (100% infill) lasted me about 12 miles before breaking, I remade it in aluminum. The part "boltmt.stl" (used with 3/16 hardware) is used to put nuts into the sides of the ESC and battery enclosures to give them a clean look.

I am using a printed wheel pulley designed by user: JuniourPotato93, and it works great.

I will upload dimensions at a later date, but leave a comment if you have any questions or want me to tweak the dimensions of one of the parts for your needs.

The resource that I found most helpful by far when building the project and choosing all of the components is this Instructables by: CoolRextreme, http://www.instructables.com/id/DIY-Electric-Longboard/ It provides an excellent crash course on all the knowledge behind the individual components needed, helping anyone to make your own knowledgeable decisions when buying the components.

Update: added spreadsheet with Bill of Materials

Future Project Idea: Hoping to be able to make a cheaper and more portable electric longboard example using a Penny/Nickel board for a future project!

Notes:

I recommend printing with infill from 50%-100% as these are structural parts.

This is a coin I designed with a phylogenetic tree which traces the evolutionary history of multiple species going inward to our common ancestor.
This holds the pieces for the board/card game Splendor - 90 cards, 40 chips and 10 tiles. The lid is included.

Organizer and lid fit.

I printed mine on a Deezmaker Bukito printer. From prior designs, I've found that I need to design a lid with about 0.04" to 0.06" extra play to fit over a rectangular thing. That is the "padding" variable in the OpenSCAD file. padding=0.02 gives 0.04" of extra space. At 0.02, I still had to sand the exterior of the base box a bit to get the lid on (and back off). Your mileage may vary.

Small footprint

My Bukito printer has only a 140x150x140 mm build volume, so I needed an organizer and lid that would each fit in that volume. All the ones I could find required two 2.5" cards side-by-side, so I could just barely make the base organizer, but not the lid. With this design, even the lid is 4.40 x 3.88".

I also wanted a design without the need for any supports.
Intestine

title: Adaptor to align camera to microscope eyepiece

description.text:
This aligns a camera with the eyepiece of a microscope.
It is currently configured for a Sony DSC-RX100, and a AMScope 10x eyepiece, but it shoud be easily modifiable to any camera eyepiece combination.
I initially tried this with a solid tube, but found it to be a bit too snug. This is a little loose, but adjustments could be made to make the spring stiffer.

title: Anet A8 Carriage for J Head

description.text:
Anet A8 Custom Carriage with Circular fan and fan bracket. This is for J-Head style Hot End with stock items from the Anet A8. I used the fan and bracket from another person whom I cannot remember where I found it from on Thingiverse...Thanks for Fan and Bracket for whom made that.!!

I used an aluminum J-Head holder made by B3 Innovations, "Groove Mount Plate."
Was printed on 1.75mm PLA at 190* @ .32 layer with 30% infill.

Hope You Enjoy it.!!

Anet A8

Yes

I've sliced case for easy printing, put camera inside and glued 2 pieces together. So, it isn't possible to extract camera without breaking the armor case. But it is also more secure as there is no chance to accidentally open the case and drop camera.
I have plans to continue working on improvements and in next version will add hand grip, lenses cover and case locks (to be able to open case).
I've attached Sketchup files for customization.

title: Hinged Mini Pelican Case 2.0
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a remix of schlem's Mini Pelican Case.
Although intended as a mini prop, this proved practical as a tiny pill box for temporary use, which looks cool as an added bonus.

The original model proved to be rather ‘dirty’ and nearly impossible to edit. Hence I rebuilt most of it to get rid of all the gaps and awkwardly connected facets, which enabled me to design an even smaller-than-mini version. The original model has an inside volume of 34x26x12 mm and can hold five SD cards. The mini model has a volume of 34x22x11.25 mm.

Another improvement is that this version has sensible tolerances for FDM printers, and an improved hinge that is less likely to detach.

Update 2017/02/18: I added a ‘v3’ version which has a much improved hinge design that is easier to print and much less prone to breaking. This hinge will also easily turn across a range of 115°. The v3 files also come in a variation with built-in supports. The v3 version is definitely the one you'll want to print, but I left the v2 models available.

The v3 version still is not an easy print though, and will require a well-calibrated printer if you want to end up with a usable result.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

A layer height of at most 0.1 mm is pretty much obligatory to ensure the details come out right.
Supports are essential for the original model with handle. The mini model might be printable without supports, but it will look a lot better with them. The v3 files are offered in a variation that has minimal built-in supports.

(If you wonder what the ugly diagonal line is in the photo of the black case, it is caused by the nozzle marring the meticulously printed top surface by doing a travel move across it. I should try enabling Z lift next time.)

The v3 version should be usable right away. Before you push the base and lid together to snap the hinge in place, check if there aren't any obvious blobs or oozing that could be in the way, and scrape it off with a knife if necessary. If the lid won't close entirely, you may have to ream the holes a bit until the little nubs fit in them.

On a well-calibrated printer, the hinge should move smoothly or have a bit of friction, but it should not be sloppy and it shouldn't require inordinate force to push it together.

These old notes only apply to the old ‘Try2’ version:
It is essential to ensure that the rod of the hinge is round, otherwise the hinges will most certainly crack. In my prints the rod always ends up a bit squashed, probably because it is the last thing to be printed and the material does not get enough time to cool down. Sand it or scrape it with a blade to adjust the shape.
Also check for “elephant's foot syndrome” (squashing of the first layer) on the little nubs and the hinge clamps, and smoothen to reduce the risk that those parts will break when clipping together the base and lid. It may be easiest to attach the lid in the 90° open position.
In the likely case that you need to print a new lid, it is recommended to print it together with something else to avoid that the little details end up as blobs due to insufficient time for cooling.
